Award.AwardTitle: Designing an Integrated Framework for Genetics Education to Develop Innovative Curricula and Assessments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Michigan State University is developing a model for integrating best practices in technology-supported instructional design and formative assessment for genetics instruction in upper elementary, middle and high school. The project partners with an urban school district in Texas and a suburban school district in Michigan. The objectives are: (1) to articulate a detailed standards- and research-base conceptual framework for describing students' conceptions of genetics and how students develop a full understanding of genetics across grade spans (upper elementary, middle and high school); (2) to develop innovative instructional materials and embedded assessments that provide richer information about students' conceptual understanding of genetics and help practitioners make decisions about what to do next in instruction; and (3) to examine the implementation of these instructional materials and assessments to investigate students' understanding of genetics concepts.

Using the Web-based Inquiry Science Environment (WISE) 4.0 platform (a technology-rich learning environment), the project is developing a 5-week elementary, middle, and secondary school curriculum models that scaffold and model scientific practices, enable students to interface with real-world problems, provide opportunities for students to make connections between visible phenomena and underlying genetic processes, and promote student monitoring and reflection on their learning. Each module will include animation- and stimulation-based contexts in WISE to provide rich occasions to press for building and developing reasoning and explanations. To promote teachers' use of student responses in formative ways, the materials will offer clear guidance about how to make evidence-based instructional decisions as well as provide options for contingent instruction activities that can be used to address persistent or common non-normative ways of reasoning.

The research offers generalizable approaches on the principled design of embedded assessments in WISE 4.0 and on using these assessments formatively. A quasi-experimental study employing a cross-sectional and longitudinal comparison design will investigate the development of students' understanding of genetics-related ideas from upper elementary to the high school years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

?      To prepare all students to compete successfully in a global economy and be knowledgeable, responsible citizens of the world, the STEMGenetics curricula, that includes grades 5, 7, and 9, have been developed to improve student outcomes in genetics learning. The goal of this project was to leverage learning technologies, specifically modules in the Web-based Inquiry Science Environment (WISE), to strengthen content understanding around the core ideas of inheritance of traits and variations of traits while engaging in scientific practices of modeling, analyzing and interpreting data, and constructing explanations.

?      The objectives for this research were threefold: (1) to articulate a detailed standards- and research-based conceptual framework for describing students’ conceptions of genetics and how students develop a full understanding of genetics across grade spans (upper-elementary, middle and high school); (2) to develop innovative instructional materials with embedded assessments that provide richer information about students’ conceptual understanding of genetics and help practitioners make decisions about what to do next in instruction; and (3) to examine the implementation of these instructional materials and assessments to investigate students’ understanding of genetics concepts.

?      During Year 1 (2011-2012) of the project, the research team focused on the design of two heredity web-based modules, content assessments and rubrics for Grades 5 and 7. The Advisory board members gave extensive feedback on the curriculum design for both grades 5 and 7.

 

?      In the second project year (2012 - 2013), we successfully accomplished planned objectives, including implementation research and professional development objectives. We made substantial refinements to project activities based on advisory board members’ feedback in the first project year. Advisors recommended: (1) collaborating with biology experts and science teachers to refine the goals of the units and ensuring that the biologists and teachers review units; (2) strengthening the links across grades and specify the trajectory for students, i.e., explicitly define the learning goals; and (3) using the Framework for K-12 Science Education (NRC, 2012) as a framework for design. Interdisciplinary collaborative design important steps were taken to respond to the advisory committee’s recommendation to include scientists and mentor teachers in the co-design process.

 

?      In the third project year (2013 - 2014), we successfully accomplished planned objectives, including curriculum design and implementation research objectives. Additionally, we achieved significant outreach goals, including communicating with congressional members, state legislators, school board leaders and local news Media. The primary curriculum design activity this year was the development of instructional materials for Grade 9, including visualizations and embedded assessments. Additional curriculum design activities included the refinements of both the materials and pre-/post-assessments for Grades 5 and 7 based on the previous year’s data.

?      In the fourth project year (2014 - 2015), the major research activities included the refinement and enactment of curriculum units, analysis of student data, development and validation of assessments, and the refinement and delivery of teacher professional development.

?      In the fifth project year (2015 - 2016), major research activities included the refinement and enactment of the Grade 9 curriculum unit, analyses of student data for Grade 7 and Grade 9, refinement and delivery of teacher professional development for Grade 9, and enactment of the Grade 9 unit in the East Lansing High School (ELHS) district.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this work included: (a) improving science instruction at the upper-elementary, middle, and high school levels, and (b) dissemination efforts, including publications in academic journals, presentation of findings at national meetings, professional development workshops for practicing upper-elementary, middle school teachers, and high school teachers. Graduate students and a postdoc were included in the research program and were part of conference presentations and publications.
